schedule.title: Arrival, Port Ground & Street Noise
schedule.details:
Arrive in Marseille and begin at the Old Port, where fishing boats, ferries, cafés, and arguments coexist openly. Walk the full curve of the harbour, letting sound, smell, and movement set expectations — Marseille introduces itself directly.

In the afternoon, move uphill into Le Panier, the city’s oldest neighbourhood. Walk slowly through tight streets, noticing colour, graffiti, hanging laundry, and sudden views back toward the sea. Pause often; Marseille rewards observation more than speed.

End the day back near the port with a seafood-focused dinner. As night falls, the city stays loud, social, and close — this is not background noise, it’s identity.

schedule.title: Sea Edges, Stone & Distance
schedule.details:
Begin the day with a coastal journey toward the Calanques National Park, where cliffs drop sharply into clear Mediterranean water. Walk selected paths rather than attempting full routes — the goal is contact, not conquest.

Spend time sitting near the water, watching light shift across stone and sea. This contrast — wild coast beside dense city — defines Marseille.

Return in the late afternoon, tired and sun-warmed. Keep the evening simple: casual food, open conversation, and a short walk near the port as the city resets for another night.

schedule.title: Height, Perspective & Farewell
schedule.details:
Begin the final day with a visit to Notre-Dame de la Garde, where views stretch across rooftops, docks, highways, and open water. From above, Marseille feels exposed rather than ordered — nothing is hidden.

Spend the remaining time revisiting favourite streets or cafés, noticing how quickly familiarity replaces intimidation. Enjoy a final lunch before departure. Marseille leaves its impression strongly — a city that doesn’t ask to be liked, only understood.

bestTime.note: Warm seas, strong light, and manageable crowds make coastal walks, calanques excursions, and harbour life vivid without peak summer heat.

worstTime.note: High summer brings intense heat and crowds, while winter mistral winds can feel harsh along the coast despite mild temperatures.

tips: Follow the water first: the Old Port, Corniche, and Calanques define the city’s true rhythm.
Plan by temperament: Le Panier (historic calm), Old Port (energy), coastal paths (space) work best as separate blocks.
Start early for the Calanques—heat and access limits build fast; check daily conditions.
Use buses or boats for coastal stretches; walking everything is exhausting under sun and wind.
Expect grit alongside beauty—Marseille rewards alert, curious travellers more than passive sightseeing.
Seafood meals anchor the day; eat late, linger long, and don’t rush the table.
withKids: Boat trips along the coast offer excitement without long walks.
Beaches and calanques require sun protection and water—shade is limited.
Stick to lively, well-lit areas in the evening.
Plan downtime—heat and stimulation can build quickly.

arrival.title: International Arrival → Marseille
arrival.note: Marseille is well connected by high-speed TGV from Paris and southern France, as well as by international flights into Marseille Provence Airport.

arrival.title: Airport or Station → City Centre
arrival.note: The airport is connected to the city by shuttle bus and train. Marseille Saint-Charles station sits above the city centre, with direct access to the Old Port via metro or on foot.

gettingAround: Walking works best in central areas such as the Old Port and Le Panier, but elevation and heat add effort.
The metro is efficient for moving between districts, especially to reduce uphill walking.
Buses are essential for coastal stretches and reaching trailheads toward the Calanques.
Boat shuttles and ferries provide perspective along the harbour and coast, acting as both transport and experience.
Taxis and ride-hailing are useful late evening or after long coastal days.

dayTrips.title: Calanques National Park
dayTrips.note: Reached by train + bus, direct bus, or boat depending on access point. Entry is regulated in summer—check daily access rules and weather before setting out.

dayMoves.title: Old Port & Central Harbour
dayMoves.note: Best explored on foot at different times of day—morning and night reveal entirely different rhythms.

dayMoves.title: Le Panier Neighbourhood
dayMoves.note: Steep, compact streets favour slow walking and frequent pauses rather than directional routes.

dayMoves.title: Coastal City Edges
dayMoves.note: Corniche paths and seaside districts are best reached by bus, then explored locally on foot.

dayMoves.title: Notre-Dame de la Garde
dayMoves.note: Reached by bus, tourist shuttle, or taxi; walking is possible but demanding, especially in heat.

practical: Separate city movement from coastal excursions—trying to combine both in one day leads to fatigue.
Heat and mistral winds affect energy more than distance; plan mornings carefully.
Public transport is reliable but slower along the coast—buffer time generously.
Boat access to calanques varies by season and weather; always confirm same-day conditions.
Stay alert but not tense—Marseille’s intensity is social, not staged.
Meals and rest anchor the day; movement should orbit them, not interrupt them.

title: Rome in 4 Days: Where Time Refuses to Move On
summary: This 4-day Rome itinerary explores a city where history is not preserved behind glass but embedded into everyday movement. Designed to balance ancient ruins, lived-in neighbourhoods, and slow meals, the itinerary invites you to experience Rome as a place where time layers rather than replaces itself — heavy, ordinary, and quietly overwhelming.
priceNote: Estimated budget per person. Excludes flights and accommodation.
highlights: Colosseum and surrounding streets at quiet hours
Walking as the primary way of seeing
A city where past and present coexist

schedule.title: Arrival & First Ruins
schedule.details:
Arrive in Rome and begin with a simple walk — ruins appear without announcement. Pass the Colosseum area without urgency, observing how traffic, cafés, and residents move alongside ancient stone.

In the afternoon, continue through nearby streets, stopping often for coffee or rest. End the day with a long dinner, accepting that time in Rome stretches naturally rather than being scheduled.

schedule.title: Layers, Stone & Repetition
schedule.details:
Spend the day exploring the Roman Forum and surrounding ruins, moving slowly and allowing scale to overwhelm rather than explain itself. Walk paths repeatedly rather than trying to see everything once.

In the afternoon, drift through adjacent neighbourhoods where laundry, scooters, and daily life sit against ancient walls. Rome reveals itself most clearly between monuments.

schedule.title: Neighbourhood Life & Long Evenings
schedule.details:
Spend the day in neighbourhoods such as Trastevere, where narrow streets, small squares, and local routines define the city’s softer side. Walk without destination, guided by shade and sound.

As evening approaches, remain in the area for dinner and late conversation. Rome slows down by extending time rather than reducing activity.

schedule.title: Morning Light & Farewell
schedule.details:
Use the final morning to revisit a favourite café or walking route. Notice how ruins feel less monumental once they become part of routine.

Enjoy a relaxed lunch before departure. Rome leaves its impression heavily — not as a highlight reel, but as a weight of time carried quietly.

bestTime.note: Mild temperatures and softer light suit long walks through ruins, piazzas, and neighbourhood streets without peak summer heat.

worstTime.note: High summer heat drains energy quickly and intensifies crowds; winter is quieter but cooler, with shorter days for outdoor wandering.

tips: Think in layers, not lists: Ancient Rome, Papal Rome, and everyday Rome deserve separate time blocks.
Start early for major sites (Colosseum, Forum, Vatican) to avoid heat and crowds; evenings belong to neighbourhoods.
Walk whenever possible—Rome’s scale is human, and its best moments appear between monuments.
Book timed entries in advance; queues can steal half-days.
Respect meal rhythm: long lunches and later dinners create natural pauses.
Carry water and sun protection—public fountains help, but heat builds fast on stone streets.
withKids: Open ruins and piazzas allow space to move between dense interiors.
Limit museum-heavy days; mix one major site with outdoor wandering.
Gelato stops are practical pacing tools.
Early starts help avoid heat and fatigue.

arrival.title: International Arrival → Rome
arrival.note: Rome is served by two main airports: Fiumicino (FCO) for most international flights and Ciampino (CIA) for budget carriers. Both connect efficiently to the city.

arrival.title: Airport → City Centre
arrival.note: From Fiumicino, the Leonardo Express train reaches Roma Termini in about 30 minutes. Taxis have a fixed city fare and are practical with luggage or late arrivals.

gettingAround: Walking is the primary way to experience Rome—many ruins, cafés, and neighbourhoods reveal themselves between destinations.
Metro lines are limited but useful for longer hops (e.g., Colosseum ↔ Termini or Vatican edges).
Buses and trams fill gaps but can be slow due to traffic; treat them as supportive rather than central.
Taxis are useful late evening or during heat, but short distances often move faster on foot.
Scooters dominate the street rhythm—be alert when crossing roads and narrow lanes.

dayMoves.title: Colosseum & Forum Area
dayMoves.note: Best approached early morning or late afternoon. Walking allows you to observe how ancient structures sit inside modern circulation.

dayMoves.title: Historic Core & Piazzas
dayMoves.note: Piazzas, cafés, and minor streets connect naturally on foot; movement here is unplanned and repetitive by design.

dayMoves.title: Trastevere Neighbourhood
dayMoves.note: Crossed easily on foot or short tram ride; once inside, walking without destination reveals the area best.

dayMoves.title: Neighbourhood Loops
dayMoves.note: Rome rewards revisiting the same routes—familiarity softens scale and reduces monument fatigue.

practical: Expect uneven surfaces—cobbles and broken stone slow walking and increase fatigue.
Heat amplifies effort: plan major walking in mornings and late afternoons.
Carry water; public fountains are frequent but not always obvious.
Avoid overusing transport—short distances often take longer by bus than on foot.
Book timed tickets in advance for major sites to protect walking time.
Rome does not compress well—leave space between activities and let the city expand.

title: Florence in 3 Days: Where Proportion Teaches Calm
summary: This 3-day Florence itinerary explores a city shaped by balance, craft, and deliberate beauty. Designed to slow attention rather than overwhelm it, the itinerary moves between early-morning landmarks, lived-in neighbourhoods, and green pauses beyond stone walls. Florence reveals itself through proportion — where clarity replaces excess and repetition deepens understanding.
priceNote: Estimated budget per person. Excludes flights and accommodation.
highlights: Arno river walks and evening light
A city built on measured beauty

schedule.title: Arrival & Early Stone
schedule.summary: Seeing the city before it performs.
schedule.details:
Arrive in Florence and begin early around the Duomo area, when stone, shadow, and space feel balanced rather than busy. Walk slowly, letting scale register without explanation.

In the afternoon, follow the Arno, crossing bridges and watching light soften façades. End the day with a long, unhurried dinner — Florence teaches patience by rewarding time spent.

schedule.title: Craft, Streets & Human Scale
schedule.details:
Spend the morning in Oltrarno, where workshops, small cafés, and neighbourhood streets reflect Florence’s craft tradition as daily life. Walk without targets, guided by sound and shade.

In the afternoon, visit Boboli Gardens for open space and perspective beyond dense streets. Return toward the river for an evening walk as the city settles into calm repetition.

schedule.title: Green Pause & Farewell
schedule.details:
Use the final morning to revisit a favourite path, café, or garden. Notice how familiarity reduces monumentality.

Enjoy a relaxed lunch before departure. Florence leaves its impression quietly — a city that teaches calm through proportion, not spectacle.

bestTime.note: Mild temperatures and softer light suit walking between churches, workshops, and viewpoints without peak summer heat.

worstTime.note: Summer heat and tour groups compress the historic core; winter is quieter but cooler, with shorter days for views.

tips: Think in balance: pair one major interior (Duomo complex or Uffizi) with an outdoor walk or piazza each half-day.
Start early for the Duomo area—light is best and crowds are lighter before mid-morning.
Cross the river daily: Oltrarno offers calmer streets and artisan workshops that reset the pace.
Book timed museum entries in advance; queues can steal precious hours.
Climb once per day at most (dome, bell tower, or Piazzale Michelangelo)—save energy and enjoy proportion.
Drink water often; stone streets radiate heat even in spring.
withKids: Compact distances make moving between sights manageable.
Piazzas provide open space between interiors.
Choose one museum per day; mix with gelato and riverside walks.
Evenings are gentle—early dinners work well for families.

arrival.title: International Arrival → Florence
arrival.note: Florence is served by Amerigo Vespucci Airport (FLR). Many visitors also arrive by high-speed train from Rome, Milan, or Venice.

arrival.title: Airport or Train Station → City Centre
arrival.note: The city centre is compact. From the airport, the tram reaches Santa Maria Novella station in about 20 minutes. From the station, most accommodation is walkable.

gettingAround: Walking is the primary way to experience Florence—distances are short and the city reveals itself best at human pace.
Buses are useful for hills or longer hops (e.g., toward Boboli edges or Piazzale Michelangelo).
Taxis are practical late evening or in heat but unnecessary for most daytime movement.
Cycling is possible but less common inside the historic core due to narrow streets and crowds.
Private vehicles are strongly discouraged within the historic centre.

dayMoves.title: Duomo & Historic Core
dayMoves.note: Best explored early morning. All major landmarks sit within a compact radius, encouraging slow loops rather than linear routes.

dayMoves.title: Arno River & Bridges
dayMoves.note: Walking along the river and crossing different bridges reveals changing perspective and light without increasing distance.

dayMoves.title: Oltrarno Neighbourhood
dayMoves.note: Reached easily on foot. Once across the river, wandering without destination suits the artisan character of the area.

dayMoves.title: Boboli Gardens
dayMoves.note: Accessed on foot from Oltrarno or by short bus ride. Movement here shifts from stone density to green pause.

practical: Historic streets are stone and uneven—comfortable walking shoes matter more than distance.
Heat builds quickly between buildings; plan major walking early or late in the day.
Museum queues can dominate time—book key entries in advance to protect walking rhythm.
Florence rewards repetition: returning to the same streets reduces crowd pressure and sharpens observation.
Avoid over-scheduling climbs; one viewpoint per day keeps the experience balanced.
Carry water—fountains exist but are less frequent than in Rome.

title: Venice in 3 Days: Where the City Floats on Patience
summary: This 3-day Venice itinerary explores a city shaped by water, fragility, and time. Designed to avoid urgency and crowds, the itinerary focuses on early hours, quiet canals, repeated walks, and lagoon light. Venice reveals itself not through speed or coverage, but through patience — a place that only opens when you move slowly enough to notice it.
priceNote: Estimated budget per person. Excludes flights and accommodation.
highlights: Grand Canal in early morning light
St Mark’s Square at dawn or dusk
A city held together by slowness

schedule.title: Arrival & First Still Water
schedule.details:
Arrive in Venice and begin with a short walk away from main routes, letting sound and water guide direction. Cross small bridges, pause often, and allow orientation to come gradually.

In the afternoon, walk along quieter canals where daily routines continue without performance. End the day near water as evening light stretches reflections across stone and surface.

schedule.title: Early Light & Vanishing Crowds
schedule.details:
Begin early at St Mark’s Square, when space, stone, and silence briefly align. Stay only long enough to feel the scale before moving back into quieter streets.

Spend the rest of the day walking without targets — repetition matters more than distance. Sit by the lagoon edge, watch boats pass, and let time loosen. Venice resists being completed.

schedule.title: Lagoon, Return Paths & Farewell
schedule.details:
Use the final morning to revisit a familiar canal or café. Notice how the city feels smaller, closer, and more human once routes repeat.

Enjoy a relaxed lunch before departure. Venice leaves its impression delicately — a city floating not on water alone, but on your willingness to wait.

bestTime.note: Comfortable temperatures and softer light make early-morning walks, vaporetto rides, and quieter sestieri exploration rewarding without peak summer crowds.

worstTime.note: Summer heat intensifies congestion, while winter brings high water, damp cold, and reduced daylight—atmospheric but less comfortable.

tips: Start early and end late: Venice is calm at dawn and after dinner—midday belongs to crowds.
Separate icons from living districts: visit St Mark’s once, then spend most time in Dorsoduro, Cannaregio, or Castello.
Walk without shortcuts—bridges and detours are part of the experience, not inefficiencies.
Use the vaporetto as transport and pause; Grand Canal rides early morning or evening offer perspective without rush.
Book timed entries for major sights; queues form quickly.
Pack waterproof shoes or overshoes outside summer—water and stone meet often.
withKids: Car-free streets make wandering safer, but watch for canals at night.
Boat rides are engaging and reduce walking fatigue.
Limit interior-heavy stops; balance with open campo squares.
Early starts help avoid crowds and overstimulation.

arrival.title: Arrival → Venice
arrival.note: Venice is reached via Marco Polo Airport (VCE) or by train to Venezia Santa Lucia. The train station opens directly onto the Grand Canal, providing an immediate sense of place.

arrival.title: Airport → Historic Venice
arrival.note: Water buses (Alilaguna) and water taxis connect the airport to the city. Water taxis are faster but expensive; Alilaguna is slower but atmospheric and practical for first-time arrivals.

gettingAround: Walking is the primary way to experience Venice—distances are short, but routes are indirect by design.
Vaporetto water buses are essential for longer canals and lagoon edges; treat rides as part of the experience, not just transport.
There are no cars, bicycles, or taxis within the historic city—movement happens at human or water speed.
Expect detours: bridges, dead ends, and canals are part of Venice’s logic, not obstacles.
Luggage should be kept light—stairs and bridges are unavoidable.

dayMoves.title: Quiet Sestieri Walks
dayMoves.note: Cannaregio, Dorsoduro, and Castello reward slow wandering away from main tourist corridors. Repetition deepens familiarity.

dayMoves.title: Grand Canal by Vaporetto
dayMoves.note: Best experienced early morning or evening when commuter rhythm replaces tour traffic and light softens façades.

dayMoves.title: St Mark’s Area (Limited Exposure)
dayMoves.note: Visit briefly at dawn or dusk, then retreat into smaller streets where Venice regains its scale.

dayMoves.title: Lagoon Edges & Campos
dayMoves.note: Open water edges and quiet squares offer places to sit, observe, and let time expand without movement.

practical: Start days early and pause midday—Venice’s calm windows are predictable.
Flooding (acqua alta) affects movement seasonally; raised walkways appear quickly but slow pace.
Maps help less than intuition—allow yourself to be briefly lost.
Bridges add vertical effort; pace yourself and plan fewer long crossings per day.
Eating near major icons inflates prices; step two streets away for better rhythm and quality.
Venice rewards repetition—returning the same way often reveals more than exploring new ground.

title: Milan in 3 Days: Where Precision Sets the Tone
summary: This 3-day Milan itinerary explores Italy’s most forward-facing city through design, discipline, and everyday efficiency. Designed to highlight clarity over romance, the itinerary balances monumental stone, modern districts, and neighbourhood evenings, revealing Milan as a place where style is functional, time is respected, and purpose shapes the pace.
priceNote: Estimated budget per person. Excludes flights and accommodation.
highlights: Modern Milan districts and design language

schedule.title: Arrival & Stone Discipline
schedule.details:
Arrive in Milan and begin early at the Duomo, when the square feels ordered and restrained. Observe the contrast between intricate stone detail and the city’s controlled movement around it.

In the afternoon, walk through nearby streets where commerce, offices, and daily routines dominate. End the day in Brera, where galleries and cafés soften the city’s edge without slowing it down.

schedule.title: Design, Modern Ground & Intent
schedule.details:
Spend the day exploring Milan’s modern districts, where architecture, fashion, and design communicate efficiency rather than ornament. Walk with purpose, noticing how space is used rather than decorated.

Pause for coffee or lunch without lingering. Milan values momentum. In the evening, return to a neighbourhood setting for a simple, well-timed meal.

schedule.title: Canals, Routine & Farewell
schedule.details:
Begin the day along the Navigli canals, where water and light offer brief softness within the city’s structure. Walk the paths without urgency, enjoying contrast rather than escape.

Enjoy a final aperitivo before departure. Milan leaves its impression clearly — a city that respects time, rewards focus, and moves forward without hesitation.

bestTime.note: Mild temperatures and active city life make walking between districts, rooftop visits, and evening aperitivo comfortable without peak summer heat.

worstTime.note: High summer heat and August closures reduce neighbourhood energy, while winter brings flat light and fewer outdoor moments.

tips: Think in clean blocks: Duomo core, Brera, and Navigli each deserve focused half-days—avoid zigzagging.
Book key experiences early: Duomo rooftop access and Last Supper tickets require advance planning.
Milan mornings are functional—save wandering and cafés for afternoons and evenings.
Aperitivo is not optional: early evening drinks double as dinner and social ritual.
Use the metro confidently—it’s fast, legible, and fits the city’s rhythm.
Dress with intention: Milan is practical, but style is expected—neutral tones travel well.
withKids: Rooftop terraces and open piazzas offer space between interior visits.
Short metro rides reduce walking fatigue.
Navigli canal paths provide relaxed evening movement.
Limit museum-heavy days—balance with outdoor neighbourhoods.

arrival.title: Arrival → Milan
arrival.note: Milan is served by multiple airports (Malpensa, Linate, Bergamo) and major rail stations. High-speed trains connect Milan efficiently with Venice, Florence, Turin, and Rome.

arrival.title: Airport → City
arrival.note: Malpensa Express trains provide the fastest and most reliable connection into the city. Linate is closer and reached easily by taxi or metro. Bergamo Airport requires bus or train transfer and adds time.

gettingAround: Milan’s metro system is fast, legible, and efficient—use it confidently for longer distances.
Walking works best within districts (Duomo core, Brera, Navigli), but distances between areas are larger than in Florence or Venice.
Trams offer slower but atmospheric movement through central streets.
Taxis are practical for evening returns or tight schedules, but traffic builds quickly at peak hours.
Milan rewards purposeful movement—plan routes rather than drifting aimlessly.

dayMoves.title: Duomo Core & Central Streets
dayMoves.note: Best explored early morning when movement is ordered and the square feels controlled rather than crowded.

dayMoves.title: Brera District
dayMoves.note: Compact and walkable, suited to galleries, cafés, and evening wandering without distance pressure.

dayMoves.title: Modern Districts & Design Zones
dayMoves.note: Reached most efficiently by metro; walking within each zone reveals how space is used rather than decorated.

dayMoves.title: Navigli Canals
dayMoves.note: Evening-focused movement: slow walking along canals followed by aperitivo rather than long-distance travel.

practical: Plan transport deliberately—Milan is efficient but spread out compared to other Italian cities.
Avoid peak metro hours (8–9am, 5–7pm) when commuters dominate.
Book Last Supper tickets weeks in advance if included; access is strictly timed.
August reduces local energy—many neighbourhood places close despite the city remaining operational.
Dress practically but intentionally—neutral, functional clothing fits local rhythm.
Milan runs on time: reservations, entries, and meals follow structure more than spontaneity.

title: Naples in 3 Days: Where Life Stands Too Close
summary: This 3-day Naples itinerary explores a city defined by proximity — to food, to people, to history, and to danger. Designed to stay close to the street, the itinerary balances dense neighbourhood walks, everyday eating, coastal light, and the looming presence of Vesuvius. Naples reveals itself through immediacy: nothing buffered, nothing softened, everything alive.
priceNote: Estimated budget per person. Excludes flights and accommodation.

schedule.title: Arrival & Street Heat
schedule.details:
Arrive in Naples and step directly into the historic centre, where streets compress sound, movement, and life into narrow corridors. Walk slowly, allowing density to guide direction rather than resist it.

Stop often for food — slices, espresso, small plates — letting appetite dictate pace. End the day still on foot, accepting noise and conversation as part of orientation.

schedule.title: Sea, Stone & Shadow
schedule.details:
Begin the day along the waterfront, where the city briefly opens toward the sea. Walk near Castel dell’Ovo and along the promenade, watching how Naples relaxes without leaving itself behind.

In the afternoon, return to interior streets and markets. Look upward — balconies, laundry, and voices form the city’s vertical layer. End the day with a long dinner that stretches late into evening.

schedule.title: Vesuvius Presence & Farewell
schedule.details:
Spend the final morning acknowledging Mount Vesuvius — from viewpoints within the city or nearby edges — a reminder of how close risk and beauty sit together here.

Enjoy a final meal before departure. Naples leaves its impression unfiltered: a city that stands too close, speaks too loud, and feeds you anyway.

bestTime.note: Warm but manageable temperatures and active street life make walking the historic centre and waterfront vivid without summer heat.

worstTime.note: High summer heat amplifies congestion and fatigue, while winter can feel grey and damp in narrow streets.

tips: Commit to the streets: Naples reveals itself at ground level—walking Spaccanapoli and surrounding lanes is essential.
Start mornings early: the historic centre is calmer before midday crowds and heat build.
Eat often and simply: pizza, sfogliatella, and street snacks pace the day better than long meals.
Plan by neighbourhood temperament: Historic Centre (intensity), Waterfront (air and space), Vomero (distance and views).
Use the metro selectively—stations are beautiful, but walking connects you to the city’s pulse.
Stay alert but relaxed: Naples rewards confidence more than caution.
withKids: Waterfront promenades offer breathing room between dense streets.
Limit long interior visits; balance churches with outdoor wandering.
Early dinners work best—streets grow louder late into the night.
Hold hands in narrow lanes and busy crossings.

arrival.title: Arrival → Naples
arrival.note: Naples is well connected by high-speed trains from Rome, Florence, and Milan. Napoli Centrale is the main rail hub and places you immediately inside the city’s intensity.

arrival.title: Airport → City
arrival.note: Naples International Airport is close to the centre. Taxis are the simplest option; buses are inexpensive but slower and more crowded.

gettingAround: Walking is essential—Naples reveals itself through proximity, sound, and street-level contact.
The historic centre is dense and best explored entirely on foot despite uneven streets.
Metro lines are useful for longer hops (Vomero, stations outside the core), but not for immersion.
Funiculars connect steep elevations and provide brief relief from street compression.
Taxis are practical at night or when heat and fatigue build, but traffic is unpredictable.

dayMoves.title: Historic Centre (Spaccanapoli & Surrounding Lanes)
dayMoves.note: Best explored slowly on foot. Narrow streets compress life vertically and horizontally—distance is short but sensory load is high.

dayMoves.title: Waterfront & Castel dell’Ovo
dayMoves.note: A linear, open walk offering air and horizon. Movement here resets the body before returning inland.

dayMoves.title: Viewpoints Toward Vesuvius
dayMoves.note: Reached by walking uphill zones or short metro/funicular rides. Views matter more than exact location.

practical: Expect friction: traffic, noise, and density are part of movement, not obstacles.
Plan walking blocks rather than distances—short routes take longer due to stops and congestion.
Heat amplifies intensity; shift movement to mornings and evenings in warmer months.
Keep belongings secure in crowded streets without becoming defensive.
Metro stations are architectural highlights but not substitutes for walking.
Naples works when transport serves survival, not efficiency.

title: Sicily in 4 Days: Where Every Civilization Stayed Awhile
summary: This 4-day Sicily itinerary explores the island as a crossroads of civilizations — Greek, Roman, Arab, Norman, and modern Italian — layered without erasing one another. Anchored in Palermo, the itinerary balances street life, ancient ruins, volcanic presence, and coastal light. Sicily reveals itself through accumulation rather than clarity, where history remains sun-worn, loud, and alive.
priceNote: Estimated budget per person. Excludes flights and accommodation.
highlights: Palermo street markets and daily life
Valley of the Temples at Agrigento
An island shaped by arrival and survival

schedule.title: Arrival & Market Heat
schedule.details:
Arrive in Palermo and step directly into its historic streets, where markets, voices, and heat fill narrow corridors. Walk slowly through street markets, where food, ritual, and argument coexist openly.

In the afternoon, explore nearby historic quarters, noticing how Arab, Norman, and Italian influences overlap rather than resolve. End the day with a long, informal dinner — Sicily introduces itself through appetite and excess.

schedule.title: Stone Layers & Southern Memory
schedule.details:
Spend the day visiting historic sites around Palermo or travel toward Agrigento to see the Valley of the Temples. Walk among ruins without rushing — columns, paths, and sky carry equal weight.

Return toward Palermo in the late afternoon, allowing distance and fatigue to soften the experience. Sicily’s past does not ask to be ordered.

schedule.title: Volcano Presence & Open Roads
schedule.details:
Use the day for a longer journey — toward Mount Etna or interior landscapes where land feels active and unsettled. You don’t need to climb; seeing Etna from distance is enough to understand how risk remains part of daily life.

Stop often along the way — villages, viewpoints, roadside cafés. Sicily rewards detours more than destinations.

schedule.title: Coast, Light & Farewell
schedule.details:
Spend the final day near the coast, where water and light stretch the island outward. Walk along the sea, sit without schedule, and let scale return gently.

Enjoy a final meal before departure. Sicily leaves its impression heavily — not through order or calm, but through the sense that everything has happened here, and something always will.

bestTime.note: Warm but not punishing temperatures, active local life, and softer light make archaeological sites, hill towns, and coastal walks comfortable and rewarding.

worstTime.note: High summer heat can overwhelm ruins and cities alike, while winter is calm but limits coastal and mountain experiences.

tips: Choose a spine, not the whole island: west (Palermo–Agrigento) OR east (Catania–Etna–Taormina). Four days is not enough for both.
Expect distances to stretch: roads are slow and winding—one major move per day is the limit.
Archaeology needs timing: visit temples and theatres early morning or near sunset when heat and crowds ease.
Food is regional even within Sicily—eat locally rather than chasing ‘best of’ lists.
Markets reveal history better than museums: Palermo and Catania street markets show layers still alive.
Carry cash—small towns, cafés, and rural stops may not accept cards.
withKids: Open archaeological sites allow movement between explanations—plan visits early in the day.
Beaches or promenades help reset after ruins and cities.
Limit long drives; choose one base and explore outward.
Sun protection is essential—shade is limited across much of the island.

arrival.title: Arrival → Palermo
arrival.note: Palermo is the most practical base for short Sicily visits. Flights arrive directly from major Italian and European cities, placing you immediately inside the island’s western rhythm.

arrival.title: Airport → City
arrival.note: Falcone–Borsellino Airport is connected to Palermo by train, taxi, and shuttle bus. Trains are reliable but slow; taxis are simpler after long travel days.

gettingAround: Walking is essential within Palermo’s historic centre—markets and neighbourhoods are dense and sensory.
Public buses cover the city but run irregularly; expect delays and adapt expectations.
Trains work between major towns (Palermo–Agrigento, Palermo–Cefalù) but are slow and limited in frequency.
A rental car offers flexibility for countryside, Etna, or coastal exploration, but city driving is chaotic.
Distances feel longer than maps suggest—movement defines the day, not the kilometres.

dayTrips.title: Agrigento – Valley of the Temples
dayTrips.note: Best approached as a full-day commitment. Early departure is essential due to distance, heat, and limited return flexibility.

dayTrips.title: Coastal Towns (e.g. Cefalù)
dayTrips.note: Shorter rail-accessible escape offering sea light and relief from city density without overextending travel time.

dayMoves.title: Palermo Historic Quarters & Markets
dayMoves.note: Explored entirely on foot. Expect compression, noise, and constant interruption—this is orientation, not efficiency.

dayMoves.title: Long-Distance Inland or Southern Routes
dayMoves.note: Road or rail journeys dominate the day. Plan one major move only; fatigue accumulates quickly.

dayMoves.title: Coastal Edges & Open Light
dayMoves.note: Linear walks along sea fronts or coastal towns reset scale after dense urban or archaeological days.

practical: Choose one directional spine only—west or east Sicily. Crossing the island in four days is unrealistic.
Heat reshapes timing: start early, rest midday, move again late afternoon.
Fuel stations and services thin out quickly outside cities—plan stops deliberately.
Cash is essential in markets, villages, and roadside cafés.
Expect unpredictability: delays, closures, and detours are normal.
In Sicily, transport is not neutral—it actively shapes experience.

title: Barcelona in 4 Days: Between Order and Instinct
summary: This 4-day Barcelona itinerary explores a city shaped by structure and spontaneity — where grids meet medieval lanes, discipline meets appetite, and art spills into daily life. Designed to balance iconic architecture, neighbourhood walking, and coastal release, the itinerary allows Barcelona to unfold through contrast rather than completion.
priceNote: Estimated budget per person. Excludes flights and accommodation.
highlights: Sagrada Família and Gaudí’s unfinished vision
Barri Gòtic and layered medieval streets
Barceloneta sea air and evening ease
A city shaped by tension and creativity

schedule.title: Arrival, Grid & First Disruption
schedule.details:
Arrive in Barcelona and begin in the Eixample district, where wide avenues and precise geometry establish a sense of order. Walk several blocks without destination, observing how balconies, cafés, and street life soften the grid from within.

In the afternoon, move toward the Sagrada Família, approaching it gradually rather than directly. The contrast between surrounding streets and the building’s organic form prepares the eye before arrival. Spend time outside as much as inside — the structure communicates as much through silhouette as detail.

End the day with dinner nearby or back in the Eixample, letting evening movement replace sightseeing pressure.

schedule.title: Old Stones, Narrow Light & Repetition
schedule.details:
Begin the day in the Barri Gòtic, walking slowly through narrow streets that twist, compress, and open unexpectedly. Let repetition guide understanding — crossing the same square twice reveals more than new territory.

In the afternoon, continue toward El Born, where craft shops, small museums, and cafés extend the medieval fabric into modern use. Pause often; Barcelona’s density rewards stillness.

As evening arrives, stay in the neighbourhood for tapas or a long shared meal. Conversation and movement naturally replace planning here.

schedule.title: Height, Colour & Controlled Chaos
schedule.details:
Begin the day climbing toward Park Güell, arriving earlier to avoid heat and crowds. From above, the city’s layers — grid, hills, sea — align clearly.

Spend time walking the park’s paths and terraces slowly, focusing on colour, form, and how the city stretches beyond.

In the afternoon, descend toward local neighbourhoods for rest and coffee, allowing energy to rebuild naturally.

End the day with a relaxed evening, keeping plans minimal. Barcelona performs best without pressure.

schedule.title: Sea Air, Release & Farewell
schedule.details:
Spend the final day near the sea, walking along Barceloneta or nearby waterfront paths. Water flattens the city’s intensity, replacing ambition with ease.

Enjoy a long lunch near the coast, then take a final walk back toward the city, noticing how familiar streets now feel navigable rather than demanding.

Barcelona leaves its impression vividly — a city held together by tension, colour, and instinct.

bestTime.note: Warm but manageable temperatures and long daylight suit walking neighbourhoods, architectural visits, and seaside evenings without peak summer heat.

worstTime.note: High summer heat and visitor numbers compress the old town, while winter is calmer but less vibrant for beach and outdoor life.

tips: Plan mornings with intent: major sights (Sagrada Família, Park Güell) reward early, focused visits.
Let afternoons loosen—cafés, markets, and neighbourhood wandering suit the city’s natural rhythm.
Separate districts by mood: Eixample (order), El Born/El Raval (instinct), Gràcia (local calm), seaside (release).
Book Gaudí sites in advance; queues form quickly and can dominate the day.
Use walking and metro together—Barcelona is flat, but distances add up.
Eat late: dinner after 8pm aligns with local life and avoids tourist rush.
withKids: Beaches and wide promenades offer space between dense city areas.
Markets and bakeries allow flexible, snack-based eating.
Limit museum-heavy days; balance architecture with outdoor movement.
Early starts help avoid heat and crowds in warmer months.

arrival.title: Arrival → Barcelona
arrival.note: Barcelona–El Prat Airport connects directly to the city via metro, train, and taxi. Transfers are efficient and legible, reflecting the city’s underlying order.

arrival.title: Airport → City
arrival.note: Metro and train provide reliable access to the Eixample and central districts. Taxis are straightforward and reasonably priced for late arrivals.

gettingAround: Walking is the primary way to understand Barcelona’s contrasts—grids, medieval lanes, hills, and waterfront connect naturally on foot.
The metro is fast, clean, and well-structured; ideal for longer jumps between districts.
Buses reveal street-level life but are slower and best used selectively.
Barcelona is largely flat, but distances accumulate—combine walking with metro to manage energy.
Cycling is popular but less practical in dense old-town areas.

dayTrips.title: Montserrat
dayTrips.note: A half- or full-day escape offering landscape, altitude, and quiet contrast to the city’s density. Best approached as a single, intentional excursion.

dayTrips.title: Sitges or Coastal Towns
dayTrips.note: Short rail-accessible seaside trips provide additional release without disrupting city pacing.

dayMoves.title: Eixample Grid Exploration
dayMoves.note: Linear walking patterns reinforce orientation and reveal how order supports everyday life.

dayMoves.title: Old Town Compression (Barri Gòtic & El Born)
dayMoves.note: Explored slowly on foot. Narrow streets and repetition replace efficiency with familiarity.

dayMoves.title: Elevated Perspective (Park Güell)
dayMoves.note: One deliberate uphill effort provides city-wide clarity and resets spatial understanding.

dayMoves.title: Seafront Release
dayMoves.note: Flat, open coastal paths reduce intensity and allow the itinerary to resolve gently.

practical: Book Gaudí sites in advance—entry slots shape the day more than distance.
Start major sights early; heat and crowds build quickly after mid-morning.
Separate days by mood rather than proximity—order, instinct, height, and release work best independently.
Carry water in warmer months; shade is uneven outside the old town.
Late dinners align with local rhythm and reduce crowd pressure.
Barcelona’s transport is efficient, but walking remains the core experience.

title: Málaga in 3 Days: Sun, Ground, and Everyday Life
summary: This 3-day Málaga itinerary explores a city shaped by sunlight, accessibility, and continuity. Designed to balance hillside history, compact cultural districts, and open coastline, the itinerary treats Málaga as a lived place rather than a resort or museum stop. Málaga reveals itself through ease — a city comfortable in its own rhythm, where daily life carries as much meaning as monuments.
priceNote: Estimated budget per person. Excludes flights and accommodation.
highlights: Picasso Museum and modern cultural layer
La Malagueta beach and sea air
A city shaped by light and routine

schedule.title: Arrival, Streets & First Orientation
schedule.details:
Arrive in Málaga and begin in the historic centre, where flat streets, open plazas, and cafés create immediate ease. Walk without direction, letting proximity and sunlight establish the city’s welcoming rhythm.

In the afternoon, visit the Picasso Museum area or nearby cultural streets, focusing on how modern life and heritage overlap naturally. Pause often — Málaga’s appeal grows through sitting as much as walking.

End the day with dinner in the old town, followed by a slow evening walk as streets remain active but unhurried.

schedule.title: Height, Stone & Mediterranean Calm
schedule.details:
Begin the day climbing toward the Alcazaba, arriving early to avoid heat and crowds. Walk the fortress walls slowly, paying attention to scale, views, and how the city stretches easily toward the sea.

Continue upward toward the Gibralfaro area if energy allows, then descend gradually back into the city. Effort and release shape Málaga’s experience.

In the afternoon, move toward Muelle Uno, where harbour paths, water, and open sky reset pace.

End the day with a seaside meal or sunset walk, letting Mediterranean light flatten the city into calm.

schedule.title: Sea Air, Repetition & Farewell
schedule.details:
Spend the final morning at La Malagueta beach or along the promenade, walking or sitting close to the water. Málaga’s coast integrates easily with daily life rather than standing apart.

Return to the centre for a final lunch, revisiting favourite cafés or streets.

Málaga leaves its impression gently — a city grounded by routine, warmed by sun, and shaped by everyday continuity.

bestTime.note: Warm days, cooler evenings, and steady light make walking the old town, climbing the Alcazaba, and enjoying the seafront comfortable without peak summer heat.

worstTime.note: High summer heat limits midday activity, while winter is mild but less lively, with shorter days and fewer outdoor evenings.

tips: Think at street level: Málaga reveals itself through plazas, bakeries, and everyday movement rather than headline attractions.
Visit the Alcazaba early morning or late afternoon to avoid heat and enjoy views with softer light.
Let meals structure the day: long lunches, light dinners, and frequent café stops fit local rhythm.
Use the port as a reset—Muelle Uno and the waterfront are ideal between dense old-town walks.
Avoid overplanning museums; one cultural stop per day is enough.
Carry sun protection year-round—brightness defines the city more than temperature.
withKids: Flat old-town streets and promenades are easy to navigate.
Beach time works best early morning or late afternoon.
Ice cream and bakery stops provide natural pacing breaks.
Limit hill climbs in midday heat—use taxis if needed.

arrival.note: Málaga–Costa del Sol Airport is close to the city and well connected by train, bus, and taxi, reinforcing the city’s reputation for accessibility and ease.

arrival.title: Airport → City
arrival.note: The suburban train reaches the historic centre quickly and reliably. Taxis are affordable and efficient for late arrivals or beach-area stays.

gettingAround: Walking is the primary way to experience Málaga—distances are short and streets are flat.

dayTrips.title: White Villages (Frigiliana or Mijas)
dayTrips.note: Short excursions into Andalusian hill towns offer texture and altitude without disrupting Málaga’s relaxed base rhythm.

dayMoves.title: Historic Centre Grounding
dayMoves.note: Flat, walkable streets encourage slow orientation and repetition rather than directional travel.

dayMoves.title: Alcazaba & Gibralfaro Ascent
dayMoves.note: One intentional climb provides historical and spatial context before releasing back into the city.

dayMoves.title: Port & Waterfront Reset
dayMoves.note: Open paths and water restore ease after stone and elevation.

dayMoves.title: Beach-Level Closure
dayMoves.note: Final movements stay horizontal and unstructured, reinforcing Málaga’s everyday continuity.

practical: Start hill climbs early or late—midday sun amplifies effort quickly.
The city works best without rigid scheduling; allow time for sitting and repetition.
Carry sun protection year-round—light intensity matters more than temperature.
Avoid car use in the centre; walking and short taxi rides are simpler.
Meals anchor the day more than attractions—plan loosely around food.
Málaga rewards familiarity: revisiting the same streets deepens understanding.

title: Madrid in 4 Days: After Dark, the City Wakes
summary: This 4-day Madrid itinerary explores Spain’s capital through art, neighbourhood life, and a nightlife rhythm that defines the city as much as its museums. Designed to balance world-class collections, open parks, and late evenings, the itinerary treats Madrid as a place best understood through time rather than spectacle. Madrid does not rush — it waits until evening to show its full self.
priceNote: Estimated budget per person. Excludes flights and accommodation.
highlights: Prado Museum and the art triangle
Gran Vía and the city’s grand arteries
Retiro Park and open green space
Malasaña and La Latina neighbourhood nights
A capital shaped by rhythm, not urgency

schedule.title: Arrival, Boulevards & First Night
schedule.details:
Arrive in Madrid and begin with a walk along Gran Vía, where scale, traffic, and light establish the city’s confidence immediately. Walk without destination, letting theatres, shops, and cafés introduce the capital’s everyday intensity.

In the afternoon, drift into nearby side streets for coffee and rest. Madrid’s density encourages pauses — energy is conserved for later.

As evening approaches, have a relaxed dinner and stay out walking afterward. The city does not peak early; Madrid begins to reveal itself properly after dark, when streets fill and time stretches naturally.

schedule.title: Art, Weight & Open Air
schedule.details:
Begin the day at the Prado Museum, choosing depth over coverage. Spend time with a limited number of works, allowing scale and gravity to settle without fatigue.

In the afternoon, move directly into Retiro Park, where trees, paths, and open space help release the museum’s weight. Walk slowly, sit often, and watch how locals use the park as an extension of living rooms.

End the day with dinner near the park or back toward the centre, keeping the evening long and unstructured.

schedule.title: Neighbourhood Streets & Night Culture
schedule.details:
Spend the morning exploring neighbourhoods such as Malasaña or La Latina, where residential streets, markets, and cafés define daily rhythm. Walk repeatedly through the same streets — familiarity matters more than novelty here.

In the afternoon, pause for a long lunch or rest. Madrid respects the afternoon slowdown.

As night arrives, return to these neighbourhoods for tapas, conversation, and unplanned movement between bars and streets. The city’s social life unfolds naturally and late.

schedule.title: Repetition, Ease & Farewell
schedule.details:
Use the final morning to revisit a favourite café, park path, or boulevard. Familiarity transforms Madrid’s scale into comfort.

Enjoy a final lunch before departure, noticing how the city remains active without urgency.

Madrid leaves its impression clearly — a place that carries culture by day and gives itself fully at night.

bestTime.note: Warm days, cooler nights, and long evenings suit late dinners, plaza life, and walking-heavy neighbourhood exploration.

worstTime.note: High summer heat compresses daytime activity, while winter shortens evenings and dampens outdoor nightlife.

tips: Shift the clock: plan sightseeing from late morning to mid-afternoon; reserve energy for evenings.
One museum per day is enough—pair it with a park or café to avoid cultural overload.
Neighbourhoods define the night: La Latina (tapas), Malasaña (bars), Chueca (late dining) each suit different moods.
Dinners start late (9–10pm); embrace tapas grazing instead of fixed meal times.
Walk between stops—central Madrid is compact and safe late into the evening.
Use the metro for late returns; it’s efficient and well-lit.
withKids: Parks like El Retiro provide space and shade during hotter hours.
Early evening tapas work better than very late dinners with children.
Pedestrian plazas allow relaxed movement after dark.
Plan shorter days—night culture can stretch energy.

arrival.title: Airport → City
arrival.note: The metro and express buses provide fast, predictable access to central Madrid. Taxis are affordable and reliable, especially for late arrivals.

gettingAround: Walking is the primary way to experience central Madrid—most key districts sit within comfortable walking distance.
The metro is clean, fast, and ideal for conserving energy for evenings.
Buses provide scenic surface travel but are slower than the metro.
Taxis are inexpensive and practical late at night when energy drops.
Cycling is possible but less integrated into daily movement than walking or metro use.

dayTrips.title: Toledo

dayTrips.title: Segovia

dayMoves.title: Boulevard Orientation
dayMoves.note: Gran Vía and surrounding arteries establish scale and rhythm through movement rather than destination.

dayMoves.title: Museum to Park Release
dayMoves.note: Pairing the Prado with Retiro Park allows weight to dissipate naturally through space and greenery.

dayMoves.title: Neighbourhood Repetition
dayMoves.note: Repeated walking within Malasaña or La Latina deepens familiarity and supports Madrid’s social rhythm.

dayMoves.title: After-Dark Flow
dayMoves.note: Late-evening movement prioritises walking between streets, bars, and plazas over fixed transport plans.

Use the metro to preserve stamina for night walking and social time.
Avoid driving; parking is limited and unnecessary in the centre.
Late-night walking is common and culturally normal in central districts.
Hydrate and rest mid-afternoon—heat and late nights compound fatigue.
Madrid feels best when revisited rather than rushed.

title: Seville in 4 Days: Living by Ritual and Heat
summary: This 4-day Seville itinerary explores Andalusia’s capital through devotion, repetition, and an unhurried relationship with heat. Designed to balance iconic monuments, shaded neighbourhood streets, and long evenings, the itinerary treats Seville not as a spectacle but as a lived system of ritual. Seville reveals itself slowly — through courtyards, bells, and the return of familiar paths.

highlights: Plaza de España and open ceremonial space
Real Alcázar gardens and layered history

A city shaped by ritual and repetition

schedule.title: Arrival, Open Stone & First Shade
schedule.details:
Arrive in Seville and begin at Plaza de España, where scale, symmetry, and openness introduce the city’s ceremonial side. Walk the curve of the plaza slowly, letting sound, tile, and light establish rhythm.

In the afternoon, move into shaded streets and gardens nearby, using benches and courtyards as natural pauses. Seville teaches pacing through contrast — openness followed by enclosure.

End the day with a relaxed dinner near your base, waiting until the air cools and streets begin to fill again.

schedule.title: Gardens, Walls & Inherited Order
schedule.details:
Begin the day early at the Real Alcázar, focusing on gardens and exterior movement rather than interiors alone. Water, tile, and enclosure define how Seville organizes space.

In the afternoon, walk through the Santa Cruz neighbourhood, where narrow streets create shade and intimacy. Walk the same routes more than once — repetition reveals orientation.

As evening arrives, stay within the old quarter for tapas and long conversation. Seville’s nights unfold gradually, without urgency.

schedule.title: Crossing the River & Everyday Seville
schedule.details:
Begin the day by crossing the Guadalquivir River into Triana, a neighbourhood shaped by craft, music, and routine rather than monuments. Walk its streets slowly, visiting small shops and cafés.

In the afternoon, return across the river or rest during peak heat hours. Seville respects withdrawal.

End the day with an evening walk along the riverbanks or a casual neighbourhood meal, when movement resumes naturally.

schedule.title: Repetition, Courtyards & Farewell
schedule.details:
Use the final morning to revisit favourite streets, courtyards, or cafés, noticing how orientation now feels intuitive.

Spend time sitting rather than moving, letting the city pass around you.

Enjoy a final lunch before departure. Seville leaves its impression deeply — a city lived by ritual, shaped by heat, and held together by time.

bestTime.note: Warm but manageable temperatures allow walking historic districts, palace gardens, and plazas without the extreme summer heat.

worstTime.note: Summer temperatures often exceed 40°C, making midday outdoor sightseeing exhausting or unsafe. Activities must shift to mornings and late evenings.

tips: Plan by sun, not clock: mornings for monuments, afternoons for rest, evenings for streets and plazas.
Book the Alcázar and Cathedral in advance—shade and indoor relief matter as much as history.
Use courtyards, gardens, and tiled interiors as cooling systems built into the city.
Cross the river to Triana in the evening for local rhythm and less tourist density.
Eat late and lightly: dinners after 9pm align with the city’s natural pace.
Hydration is not optional—carry water even in cooler months.
withKids: Gardens and shaded courtyards provide natural cooling and space to pause.
Limit outdoor activity between 1–5pm in warmer seasons.
Evening walks and early tapas suit family energy better than late nights.
Hats, sunscreen, and refillable water bottles are essential.

Taxis are practical during midday heat or late evenings when energy drops.

dayTrips.title: Carmona

dayMoves.note: Movement alternates between open ceremonial spaces (Plaza de España) and shaded streets or courtyards.

dayMoves.title: Shade-Based Navigation

dayMoves.title: River Crossing Reset
dayMoves.note: Crossing into Triana provides social and spatial contrast without leaving the city’s rhythm.

dayMoves.title: Evening Reoccupation
dayMoves.note: Movement resumes after sunset, with walking as the dominant mode during cooler hours.

practical: Avoid rigid schedules—heat dictates movement more than time.
Plan transport around recovery: walking early and late, taxis or trams midday.
Driving is unnecessary and impractical within the historic core.
Carry water at all times; public fountains and shade are part of the city’s design.
Rest is cultural, not wasted time—withdrawal enables evening life.
Seville rewards returning to the same streets rather than expanding outward.

title: Valencia in 3 Days: Light, Space, and Forward Motion
summary: This 3-day Valencia itinerary explores a city shaped by openness and intention — where a former riverbed became a green spine, modern architecture embraced the future, and the Mediterranean remains within reach. Designed to balance historic streets, expansive public space, and coastal ease, the itinerary reveals Valencia as a place that moves forward calmly, guided by light and proportion rather than urgency.

schedule.title: Arrival, Old Stones & Civic Calm
schedule.details:
Arrive in Valencia and begin in the historic centre, where plazas, churches, and civic buildings sit comfortably without density or pressure. Walk through Plaza de la Virgen and surrounding streets slowly, noticing how space opens naturally between landmarks.

In the afternoon, continue through nearby neighbourhood streets, pausing often for coffee or shade. Valencia’s historic core feels navigable rather than compressed — orientation arrives easily.

End the day with a relaxed dinner nearby, keeping the evening simple and grounded.

schedule.title: Green Spine, Modern Vision & Scale
schedule.details:
Begin the day walking or cycling through the Turia Gardens, a long green corridor built in a former riverbed. Moving through the park reveals how Valencia chose openness as its future.

Continue toward the City of Arts and Sciences, arriving gradually rather than directly. Spend time walking the exterior paths, bridges, and reflecting pools — the architecture communicates through movement and proportion more than detail.

In the afternoon, rest in shaded areas or cafés nearby before returning toward the centre.

End the evening with a long meal, allowing daylight to fade slowly across the city.

schedule.title: Sea Air, Familiar Paths & Farewell
schedule.details:
Spend the final day near the coast, walking along Malvarrosa Beach or nearby promenades. The Mediterranean flattens the city’s ambition into ease.

Enjoy a long lunch by the sea, then return inland for a final walk through familiar streets.

Valencia leaves its impression gently — a city that trusted space, light, and forward motion to shape everyday life.

bestTime.note: Warm but comfortable temperatures and bright, steady light make walking the Turia Gardens, exploring the old town, and enjoying the beach ideal without summer heat.

worstTime.note: High summer heat limits daytime walking, while winter is mild but less lively for outdoor evenings and beach time.

tips: Use space as relief: the Turia Gardens are the city’s backbone—walk or cycle them daily between districts.
Separate eras: give the old town and the City of Arts & Sciences their own time blocks to avoid contrast overload.
Plan by light: mornings suit historic streets, afternoons fit modern architecture and parks, evenings belong to the sea.
Eat locally and on time: lunch is long, dinner late—paella is traditionally a midday meal.
Cycling works exceptionally well here; flat terrain and green routes reduce transport friction.
Stay hydrated and sun-aware—Valencia’s brightness is constant even outside summer.
withKids: The Turia Gardens offer playgrounds, shade, and safe cycling paths.
Science City spaces are visually engaging without needing long explanations.
Beach mornings are calmer and cooler than afternoons.
Flat streets and parks make moving between areas easy.

dayMoves.note: Morning and late-afternoon movement prioritises openness and shade; midday favours rest or park-based circulation.

practical: Driving is unnecessary—Valencia’s layout supports walking, cycling, and public transport seamlessly.

Plan transport around light rather than urgency; Valencia rewards measured pacing.
Beach access is easiest by tram or bike rather than car.

title: Granada in 3 Days: Water, Shadow, and Patience
summary: This 3-day Granada itinerary explores a city shaped by water, enclosure, and deliberate slowness. Designed to balance the Alhambra’s quiet power with neighbourhood walking and evening stillness, the itinerary treats Granada as an experience of atmosphere rather than accumulation. Granada asks for patience — and rewards it with depth, shade, and memory.
priceNote: Estimated budget per person. Excludes flights and accommodation.
highlights: Mirador de San Nicolás at dusk
Old town markets and tea houses
A city shaped by water and restraint

schedule.title: Arrival, Old Streets & First Stillness
schedule.summary: Letting the city slow you down.
schedule.details:
Arrive in Granada and begin in the historic centre, where narrow streets, small plazas, and shopfronts create immediate enclosure. Walk without urgency, allowing shade and sound to recalibrate pace.

In the afternoon, explore the area around the cathedral and nearby markets, pausing often for tea or coffee. Granada introduces itself quietly — familiarity forms through repetition rather than coverage.

As evening approaches, walk toward the lower slopes of the Albaicín, watching light soften against white walls. End the day with a calm dinner nearby, keeping the night unhurried.

schedule.title: Stone, Water & Measured Wonder
schedule.summary: Meeting the city’s centre of gravity.
schedule.details:
Begin early at the Alhambra, arriving before heat and crowds. Move through the palaces slowly, focusing on courtyards, water channels, and shadowed thresholds rather than trying to absorb everything at once. The Alhambra communicates through repetition — arches, reflections, sound.

Continue into the Generalife gardens, where water, paths, and elevation allow the mind to settle after architectural density.

In the late afternoon, descend gradually back toward the city, resting often. End the day with a simple meal and early night — Granada expects recovery.

schedule.title: Hillside Paths, Evening Light & Farewell
schedule.details:
Spend the morning walking deeper into the Albaicín, climbing slowly through residential streets and small squares. The neighbourhood reveals itself through effort and return.

In the afternoon, pause for lunch and rest, conserving energy for the evening.

As dusk approaches, walk to Mirador de San Nicolás and wait. The Alhambra across the valley glows softly as sound fades and shadow deepens.

Granada leaves its impression gently — a city that never rushes, and never needs to.

bestTime.note: Comfortable temperatures and softer light make hill climbs, Alhambra visits, and evening miradores manageable and atmospheric.

worstTime.note: Summer heat makes midday walking punishing, while winter evenings can be surprisingly cold once the sun drops.

tips: Time the Alhambra precisely: book tickets well in advance and aim for early morning or late afternoon entry to avoid heat and crowds.
Respect vertical effort: Albaicín and Sacromonte climbs are slow by nature—plan fewer stops and allow recovery time.
Follow water lines: fountains, channels, and gardens cool the body and pace the day.
Rest mid-afternoon: Granada follows a natural pause—embrace it rather than pushing through heat.
Miradores work best at dusk; daylight flattens the drama, shadow brings it back.
Evenings belong to tapas—small plates pace energy better than full dinners.
withKids: Gardens and courtyards provide shade and space to reset between climbs.
Limit hill-heavy days to one major ascent.
Evening viewpoints are visually engaging without long explanations.
Carry water constantly—shade does not mean cool.

arrival.title: Arrival → Granada
arrival.note: Granada is most commonly reached by train or bus from major Andalusian cities such as Seville, Málaga, or Madrid. Arrival feels immediate and compact rather than infrastructural.

arrival.title: Station / Bus Terminal → City
arrival.note: The historic centre is a short taxi or bus ride from arrival points. Transfers are brief and orientation begins quickly once inside the old town.

gettingAround: Walking is the primary way to experience Granada; most meaningful movement happens on foot.
Local buses are useful for uphill routes toward the Alhambra and Albaicín, especially in heat or after long days.
Taxis are practical for short climbs or evening returns but unnecessary within the compact centre.
Driving is discouraged—narrow streets and restricted zones make cars inefficient.

dayTrips.note: A short escape into mountain air and elevation, offering contrast to Granada’s enclosure without requiring a full travel day.
